awd_titl_txt: Robust Multilevel Preconditioning Techniques for Elliptic PDE with Variable Coefficients
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research is to design robust preconditioners for solving the finite element discretization of second order elliptic PDEs with variable coefficients and then apply these preconditioners in developing efficient iterative solvers for Maxwell's equations and H(div) equations. The PI shall develop, analyze and implement nearly optimal iterative solvers for elliptic PDE with variable coefficients, especially multiscale elliptic PDEs. Based on several successful preliminary investigations, the PI will design robust multilevel preconditioners for various types of finite element discretization, such as conforming, nonconforming,  discontinuous Galerkin discretization and mixed formulation of second order elliptic PDEs with general variable coefficients on both structured and unstructured bisection grids. The approach will be based on the auxiliary space preconditioning framework. This technique will be proved to be robust with respect to both the variations in the coefficients and the grid size for solving general multiscale elliptic PDEs. The research will allow one to choose different coarse grid problems other than the standard variational coarse grid problems in the preconditioners. Upon obtaining robust preconditioners for various finite element discretizations, the PI will then use these preconditioners to develop robust iterative solvers for Maxwell's equations and H(div) equations with variable coefficients using the auxiliary space preconditioning techniques. The algorithms will be implemented as open source software packages which will be used in collaborations with domain-specific scientists. 

This project has broad impact in education and other areas of mathematics, engineering, and physics through software development. The methods to be developed will contribute to the advancement of numerical methods for both linear and nonlinear systems. The research results will provide powerful tools for the exploration of important models such as reservoir simulations and electromagnetic computation. The project enriches the graduate program in the Department of Mathematics at ISU, especially in the area of partial differential equations and numerical analysis. The research shall involve undergraduate and graduate students, and excellent mentoring shall be provided by the PI.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This proposal was concerned with design, analysis and implementation of robust and efficient multilevel iterative solvers for the finite element approximation of the second order elliptic parital differential equations with discontinuous coefficients. These partial differential equations describe a wide range of science and engineering processes, such as groundwater/reservoir simulations and electromagnetic computation in composite materials. Due to the heterogeneity in the coefficients, the discretization schemes require extremely fine grids to capture the correct behavior of the solution, which leads to large-scaled discrete linear systems that need to be solved. It is critical to develop efficient solvers which are robust with respect to variations in coefficients and problem sizes. 

The project has resulted in a class of efficient multilevel algorithms for solving the finite element discretization of second order elliptic equations with discontinuous coefficients on highly unstructured adaptive grids. These algorithms used a local smoothing technique to achieve the optimal computational complexity. They were proved to be robust with respect to the variations in coefficients and problem sizes. Some efficient multilevel algorithms were developed and analyzed for more general reaction and diffusion equations with discontinuous coefficients. These results lead to easily implementable, robust and efficient iterative solvers for the problems with discontinuous coefficients.

Though the focus of the project was on multlevel iterative solvers, progresses in analyzing the related discretization methods for some more challenging nonlinear partial differential equations have also been made. In particular, the project gave a first goal-oriented adaptive finite element algorithm for semilinear PDE with provable convergence. We also developed the error analysis for the finite element approximations of the linear and semilinear evolution problems using the finite element exterior calculus framework. This project also provided a set of results on analyzing the uniqueness of the discrete solution for a large class of quasilinear partial differential equaitons. These results are the first uniqueness results for this type of problem that do not require the restrictive globally fine mesh conditions.

The methods and analysis developed in this project lead to near optimal complexity algorithms for reliable and efficient numerical simulations in many science and engineering applications. Some of these algorithms have been incorporated in a pilot undergraduate/graduate Numerical Linear Algebra course at Idaho State University in 2017. Two highly motivated master students from this course are currently enrolled in the interdisciplinary Engineering and Applied Sciences PhD program at Idaho State University. 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2017
Modified by: Yunrong Zhu
